item.title: Setting up quotas on Linux
item.description:
Introduction link

The assignment of quotas in a file system is a tool that allows control of disk space usage. Quotas consist of setting a space limit for a user or a group of users.

For the creation of these quotas, 2 types of limits are defined:

  • The soft limit: indicates the maximum amount of space that a user can occupy on the file system. If this limit is reached, the user receives warning messages about exceeding their assigned quota. When used in combination with grace periods, if the user continues to exceed the soft limit after the grace period has elapsed, they will face the same restriction as when reaching a hard limit.

item.title: PhpPgAdmin: Installation and Configuration
item.description:
Introduction link

PhpPgAdmin is equivalent to phpMyAdmin for those who know it. It allows you to administer PostgreSQL through a small web interface.

Installation link

To install it:

 apt-get install phppgadmin

Then, to choose which web server to run on (otherwise we have to do it manually):

 dpkg-reconfigure phppgadmin

Configuration link

To allow connections from an external machine, modify the file /etc/phppgadmin/apache.conf and add:

item.title: Windows: Stop a system shutdown in progress
item.description:
Sometimes it’s necessary to create scripts that reboot your machine after modifications. Or you may have caught a virus that tells you your PC will reboot in x seconds.

To cancel this reboot, simply use:

 shutdown -a

item.title: Windows: Refreshing Security Policies (GPO)
item.description:
Instead of closing and reopening your session to verify that security policies are working properly, there are commands to avoid disconnecting.

  • Windows 2000:
 secedit /refreshpolicy machine_policy /enforce
  • Windows XP:
 gpupdate /force

item.title: Fanout: Run the Same Command on Multiple Machines Simultaneously
item.description:
These two tools by William Stearns can quickly become essential when managing multiple machines…

As indicated in the title, these tools allow you to run commands simultaneously on multiple machines, and even interactively (with fanterm).

I didn’t find anything in the repositories or as a .deb package. So I “alienated” the rpm:

 wget http://www.stearns.org/fanout/fanout-0.6.1-0.noarch.rpm
sudo alien fanout-0.6.1-0.noarch.rpm
sudo dpkg -i fanout_0.6.1-1_all.deb
